awd_titl_txt: Human Occupation Of Persistent Coastal Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Erich Fisher, of Arizona State University, and colleagues from South Africa and many other nations will study how hunter-gatherers lived in persistent coastal contexts during glacial and interglacial phases. For many years, scholars have studied how people interact with their environment when faced with ecological pressures. Like modern people, prehistoric hunter-gatherers are known to have adapted their subsistence, technological, and social behaviors in response to changes in their local environments. These adaptations influenced, among other things, what they ate, where they lived, what kinds of tools they made, and also how they interacted with each other. The archaeological sciences are ideally suited to studying the relationship between people and their environment over long timespans - spanning centuries to tens of thousands of years - because these kinds of behavioral changes can be detected in the multivariate archaeological record. Coastal zones are dynamic and rich environments with abundant, diverse, and predictable foods and other resources. Scholars have been intrigued by the way coastal environments may have supported and even protected humans living in these places from larger ecological changes that detrimentally affected human groups living in inland locations. Yet considerable gaps remain in these records due to changes in sea levels during glacial phases that shifted the locations of many coastlines by tens to hundreds of kilometers. Understanding how hunter-gatherers adapted to coastal zones over long timeframes, and how these groups compared to populations living inland, therefore, provides new insights into the ways that humans used subsistence, social and technological strategies to mediate ecological pressures in dynamic environments. It also gives the scientific community a broader point of reference for understanding human impacts on coastal environments, which can inform 21st century marine and coastal conservation strategies.
 
South Africa has one of the oldest and richest records of human coastal occupation. This research project focuses on South Africa's East Coast where very narrow continental shelf has limited coastline movements during glacial periods. This prevented large coastline movements and created stable coastal ecosystems. In one these places, known as Pondoland, rare records of coastal occupation and resource use during the Last Glacial Maximum (ca. 26,000-19,000 years ago) have already been recovered by the P5 Project. These records provide a unique opportunity to study hunter-gatherers living in stable coastal contexts over long time periods and compare evidence of their behaviors to hunter-gatherer groups living inland. The project synergizes researchers from numerous international universities and disciplines to answer complex questions about the evolution of human behavior in a unique and persistent environment along Pondoland's coastline. Detailed archaeological, zooarchaeological, and paleoenvironmental information from excavations at two coastal archaeological sites will be collected as well as datasets from systematic landscape studies and ethnographic observations of modern plant foods and coastal foraging. The research will generate new evidence to test questions about coastal ecological variability across glacial and interglacial periods and how these changes impacted hunter-gatherer food-choice patterns, social networks, settlement patterns, and technology. Situating these data within the broader southern African paleolandscape will bring renewed focus on hunter-gatherer's use of coastal and inland resources across glacial and interglacial cycles and it will provide a more nuanced understanding of human evolution and social complexity across broad bio-geographical contexts. The project's interdisciplinary datasets, therefore, will provide detailed insights into past human behavior, humans' long-term impacts on coastal ecology, local environmental changes that influenced various biotic communities, and new methods to conserve these resources for future generations.

por.por_cntn:
Humans have relied on marine coastlines and coastal resources for hundreds of thousands of years because these places provided abundant and predictable marine and terrestrial foods and other resources to support hunter-gatherers. Yet considerable gaps remain in our understanding of when, where, and how past people began to rely on coastal resources. Consequently, researchers still do not fully understand the role that coastlines played in the evolution and survival of the modern human lineage.

This project hypothesized that coastal zones influenced hunter-gatherer risk responses during deleterious times, including their technological organization, subsistence strategies, and settlement practices. To test these hypotheses, the Mpondoland Paleoclimate, Paleoenvironment, Paleoecology, and Paleoanthropology Project (P5) coordinated an international and interdisciplinary team of researchers in Mpondoland, Eastern Cape Province, South Africa to study coastal occupation and foraging during the Last Glacial Maximum and across a glacial/interglacial transition.

Our research in Mpondoland provides a window into hunter-gatherer behavior across a glacial/interglacial transition in a persistent coastal context. Detailed excavations at the Waterfall Bluff rock shelter document a complex and well-preserved archaeological record of human activity across the end of the Pleistocene, from ca. 36,000 years ago, and into the Holocene up to ca. 8,000 years ago. The Waterfall Bluff radiocarbon and luminescence chronology is now among the most robust for the Late Pleistocene in southern Africa, providing a new and important benchmark to other studies in the region.

Detailed multi-proxy paleoenvironmental analyses compliment the archaeological records. These data show that all major vegetation zones were sustained during the Late Pleistocene and early Holocene, including during the Last Glacial Maximum. Analysis of archaeological faunal remains further suggests a mosaic of environments surrounding the rock shelter that included grasslands, bushy, and forested environments. Remains of aquatic plants provide additional evidence for locally available freshwater near the rock shelter across the Late Pleistocene and Early Holocene while evidence of medicinal plant remains attests to a broad-based reliance on the natural environment that supported the needs of prehistoric people.

Notably, the Waterfall Bluff deposits preserve the first direct evidence of coastal foraging during a glacial maximum and across a glacial/interglacial transition. Our data show that people during the Last Glacial Maximum and across the Pleistocene / Holocene transition repeatedly targeted coastal--and likely estuarine--environments for a variety of resources including marine shellfish, estuarine fish, marine mammals, but also woody vegetation common to coastal forests. These data create a tangible and multi-facetted link between the archaeological records at Waterfall Bluff and the coast. These records are complimented by our multi-year ethnographic study of modern amaPondo foragers, which shows that modern amaPondo foragers also often target estuaries simultaneously for fuelwood and intertidal resources.

There is as yet no evidence that coastal hunter-gatherers at Waterfall Bluff lacked resources for their survival or had to travel long distances for those resources. Everything that has been documented to date could have been found locally. There is also no evidence for substantial gaps between the occupations at Waterfall Bluff. This observation is at odds with apparent region-wide redistributions of inland hunter-gatherer populations during the Last Glacial Maximum on account of climatically-driven changes in resource availability. The main draw of places like Waterfall Bluff, therefore, may not have been the presence of one resource versus another, but the combination of all the resources within a centralized location. Other terrestrial fauna plus additional plant resources, like corms, tubers, fruits, and edible leaves would have also been available on the exposed continental shelf or inland around the site.

The project utilized a multidisciplinary collaborative learning network, placing a strong emphasis on integrating high-caliber early career researchers with experienced academics to collaborate on research output that is directly relevant to the natural and social sciences. It fostered international collaborations that strengthened South Africa's research capacity (with flow on benefits for that nation and future international researchers working there), as well as providing excellent opportunities for emerging researchers in the US and abroad to develop their own independent careers. To date, two students have submitted Bachelors of Arts Honours theses from output generated by this project. Our project also provided substantive data about the local ecology to support local conservation strategies and manage resource depletion and sustainability in marine protected areas and local nature reserves. Our close collaboration with traditional amaPondo leaders and communities built trust and showed respect to local people, their beliefs, and knowledge systems. We also partnered with Jive Media South Africa to develop a bilingual comic book that uses a locally-driven narrative of female scientific empowerment, sovereignty, and community engagement to communicate basic information about archaeological science and careers in archaeology to South African primary and high school students. It is the first project of its kind in South Africa. The comic books are available freely online and in hardcopy.
